image.altText: Two black and white images of the men in suits.

items.synopsis: For the first time, the criminal trial over the deadly White Island eruption hears evidence from the three brothers who own the volcano.

title.children: In 1936, George Buttle wrote a number on a piece of paper and bought White Island. Now his grandsons give evidence

image.altText: Donald Trump frowns in a mugshot, wearing a suit and red tie

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump hands himself in to authorities in Fulton County, Atlanta, to be arrested over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the state's 2020 election results.

title.children: Donald Trump hands himself in over Georgia election indictment

image.altText: A man and a woman look at the camera with plain expressions on their faces.

items.synopsis: A couple who had their embryos destroyed in a bacteria breach at a Sydney fertility clinic say they have not received an apology or offers of compensation.

title.children: Vikki and Chris thought their IVF woes were over, then their embryos were destroyed

image.altText: A smartly dressed man speaks at a press conference.

items.synopsis: The need to rebuild WA's opposition isn't on the official agenda, but it's at the heart of a crucial Nationals Party gathering this weekend, writes state political reporter Keane Bourke.

title.children: Crunch time for WA's major opposition party as it faces difficult choices — with one big elephant in the room

image.altText: A female tick biting the skin of a human.

items.synopsis: With ticks thriving after La Niña, more people are expected to be bitten by the parasites, and that could lead to an increase in cases of a potentially life-threatening meat allergy.

title.children: After three wet summers, these tiny creatures are booming. They could make you allergic to red meat

image.altText: A centrifuge with a launch spout against a morning sky, clouds pink with sunrise.

items.synopsis: Spinlaunch is looking at several sites around the globe, including two on the south coast of Western Australia, to build its orbital accelerator.

title.children: US spaceflight company considering Australia for space slingshot to catapult rockets into orbit

image.altText: Two heat maps of Australia which show temperatures in Western Australia will increase more than in other parts.

items.synopsis: The latest Intergenerational Report predicts we will live longer, we'll be more highly skilled, and we'll have to live under hotter temperatures. Here's what this could mean for our future.

title.children: These six charts show what Australia could look like in 40 years

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price looking to the left during a nationals press conference

items.synopsis: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has implied the government gave unequal treatment to the Yes and No campaigns by "fumbling" the latter's DGR status. Is that correct?

title.children: Did Labor treat the No campaign differently on its tax status?

image.altText: A composite image of Yegveny Prigozhin and Vladimir Putin

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin offers his condolences after a plane crash that authorities say killed Wagner Group chief Yevgeny Prigozhin.

title.children: Putin breaks silence after plane crash that Russia says killed Prigozhin

image.altText: The smoking wreckage of a jet with firefighters standing around it

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin takes security seriously, using fake names and body doubles to make himself difficult to trace — it's one of the reasons these experts are sceptical about reports of his death.

title.children: Fake names and body doubles: Why there could be more to the crash that 'killed' Yevgeny Prigozhin

image.altText: Two Aboriginal children smiling at each other

items.synopsis: The Wirriya Dunyji Ooba Babanil Ingun early years community plan, launched in Derby, recommends a raft of changes to improve life for the town's youngest residents.

title.children: Kimberley community writes own plan for 'happy, strong, small children' to thrive

image.altText: An older and young man stand next to tractor-looking robot in a paddock with stubble, blue skies.

items.synopsis: With a few beeps and a slight rev of the engine, Alfie, the autonomous sprayer, sets off to work. He may be the best new recruit on this farm.

title.children: Why 'Alfie' the crop-spraying robot is the answer to this farm's most tedious job

image.altText: man with tattoos on neck in black shirt looks seriously at camera

items.synopsis: He may look like he's fully recovered from a serious car crash but, a year on, Cooper Maher is still silently suffering the impacts of a brain injury.

title.children: Cooper was thrown from a car in a horrific crash. He now suffers an invisible disability

image.altText: Grey spherical rocks sit in the sand next to blue ocean

items.synopsis: UNESCO will write to the WA government asking for better protection for stromatolites at Hamelin Pool as a viewing platform damaged two years ago remains broken.

title.children: Fears tourists are trampling world's oldest 'living fossils' at heritage-listed reserve

image.altText: wrestler windham Rotunda at a press conference

items.synopsis: WWE wrestler Windham Rotunda, who went by the stage name Bray Wyatt, is being remembered as a "defining superstar of his generation" after dying at the age of 36.

title.children: Professional wrestler Windham Rotunda dies aged 36

image.altText: An older man wearing a shirt

items.synopsis: A victim of convicted paedophile Milton Orkopoulos tells a Sydney court the disgraced parliamentarian "ruined" him by giving him "a taste of drugs" as a child, leading to a life of addiction, incarceration and confusion.

title.children: Victim says former NSW Labor minister 'ruined' him by giving him 'a taste of drugs' as a child

image.altText: Scooter Braun stands next to Justin Bieber on a red carpet

items.synopsis: Music stars are reportedly leaving manager Scooter Braun, who Taylor Swift once called an "incessant manipulative bully".

title.children: Justin Bieber and Ariana Grande have reportedly dumped their high-profile manager. Here's what we know

image.altText: Matildas players cheer reacting to a penalty shoot out in a large stadium

items.synopsis: They may not have won their home Women's World Cup, but in performing the way they did, the Matildas have achieved something far greater than silverware.

title.children: 'I told you so': Matildas' World Cup heroics have won Australian football's biggest fight

image.altText: Six passports with details blurred out sitting open on a table.

items.synopsis: The 10 foreigners Singapore police arrested last week in a massive anti-money-laundering operation were citizens of countries including China, Vanuatu, Cyprus, Türkiye and Cambodia. But it's since emerged they were all originally from the same place.

title.children: 'Golden passports': Where did the suspects in Singapore's new billion-dollar money laundering case come from?

image.altText: The leaders of Brazil, China, South Africa and India and Russia's foreign minister hold hands as they pose for a photo.

items.synopsis: Iran, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Argentina, Egypt and Ethiopia are set to join the group next year, potentially bringing three of the biggest oil producers into a bloc China and Russia have been keen to expand to raise their geopolitical influence.

title.children: Six more countries set to join China and Russia in the BRICS economic bloc

image.altText: a composite image of the outdoor of two major retail outlets

items.synopsis: A highly anticipated speech by the US Federal Reserve chairman on the state of the US economy has global markets on edge after sending Wall Street lower, while Wesfarmers has reported a near-5 per cent rise in profits. Follow live.

title.children: Bunnings, Kmart boost profits for Wesfarmers, markets 'twitchy' ahead of US Federal Reserve speech, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you didn't know, August 25 is Equal Pay Day — and the date itself is no accident. August 25 represents the 56 days from the beginning of the new financial year, which is the number of days women must work to earn the same as men did last year, on average. "The 56 extra days that women have to work to earn the same, on average, as men, shows us that these barriers are still significant in Australian workplaces," Workplace Gender Equality Agency CEO Mary Wooldridge said. "It means that women are missing out on 13 cents, on average, for every $1 that a man makes. "Currently at 13%, the gender pay gap in Australia is a persistent and pervasive issue that undermines women’s earnings ." So what can be done? The WGEA, which is an agency of the federal government, says today is a reminder that employers need to "eliminate the barriers of bias, discrimination and entrenched gender stereotypes tha t devalue women and their work and drive the gender pay gap". "Today’s Equal Pay Day is a call to action for all employers to build on this moment by taking the time to find out what steps they need to take to support greater gender equality in their own workplace," Ms Wooldridge said. From next year, the WGEA will publish the gender pay gap for employers that have 100 or more workers in Australia, which it says will help tackle gender inequality through "increased transparency and action".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Today is Equal Pay Day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lithium miner Pilbara Minerals posted a net profit of $3.4 billion in the last financial year — an enormous 326% increase compared to a year earlier thanks to soaring lithium prices — but it's value has slumped significantly on the market today. That's because its production outlook for the coming year is lower than what was expected, with the miner expecting to produce between 660-690,000 tonnes of spodumene concentrate in the next financial year. Forecasts expected that range to be upwards of 700,000 tonnes — and it's that shortfall that's seen it's share price slide into the red. But the miner says the long-term outlook remains "very positive" for lithium. As of 12:30pm AEST, Pilbara shares were down 7.1% to $4.75 .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pilbara Minerals slides despite massive profit on weak outlook of lithium output

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier in the blog we covered the financial regulator taking subsidiaries of IAG to court for misleading customers over home insurance discounts. IAG has now released a statement about the proceedings, which it says it plans to defend. Here's their statement in full: "IAG acknowledges the civil penalty proceedings commenced by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) in the Federal Court of Australia against IAG’s subsidiaries Insurance Australia Limited (IAL) and Insurance Manufacturers of Australia Pty Limited (IMA). "The proceedings allege contraventions of the ASIC Act and the Corporations Act concerning the pricing of, and certain disclosures about how premiums are priced, for renewing customers of SGIO, SGIC and RACV home insurance products. "IAL and IMA maintain they have delivered on loyalty promises made to customers, do not agree that they have misled customers about the extent of the discounts they would receive, and intend to defend the proceedings ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IAG 'intend to defend' misleading insurance lawsuit brought by ASIC

image.altText: An image of Popstar P!nk singing into a micophone next to an image of the Townsville CBD

items.synopsis: Some P!nk fans are planning to sleep in tents, as hotels and Airbnbs charge thousands of dollars a night to secure a bed during the popstar's surprise north Queensland tour leg.

title.children: 'Stiffing families': Room prices skyrocket amid ticket frenzy for P!nk's surprise Townsville concerts

image.altText: A woman holding a pride flag at a rally.

items.synopsis: Transgender people are stuck on waiting lists for years and spending tens of thousands of dollars to access gender-affirming surgery, but now an application has been made to list the procedures as specific Medicare items.

title.children: Trans Australians waiting years for gender-affirming surgery, as Medicare bid looms

image.altText: A sign depicting a shark with the words 'swimming not advised' on a long, empty beach.

items.synopsis: Surfers help victim to shore and apply first aid before paramedics rush him to Port Macquarie Base Hospital for treatment to leg wounds.

title.children: Man, 44, in critical condition after being bitten by a shark on NSW Mid North Coast

image.altText: A man in a shirt and jacket sits at a wooden table and smiles for the camera.

items.synopsis: Victoria Police has confirmed detectives from the Sexual Crimes Squad are investigating the Member for Ringwood, Will Fowles. He has refuted any allegation of assault.

title.children: Police investigate alleged assault by Victorian MP Will Fowles

image.altText: The polluted air captured in the Monas monument in Jakarta on 11 August 2023.

items.synopsis: Jakarta residents dealing with some of the worst air quality in the world are told to wear masks and work from home, with some contemplating moving to Bali.

title.children: As Jakarta's air quality gets worse, residents consider moving to Bali where the pollution is only moderate

image.altText: Several bees flying through the air and landing on a brown wooden board.

items.synopsis: Varroa mite has been in Australia for more than a year, but there are now fears it will spread between states, creating enormous uncertainty for the horticulture industry.

title.children: Deadly bee pest spreads to Victorian border, sparking food production fears

image.altText: A group of school children eat sandwiches near a park.

items.synopsis: Public health researchers are concerned rising cost of living pressures are opening the door to serious Victorian-era diseases like scurvy.

title.children: Risk of scurvy, rickets rising amid food affordability crisis, researchers warn

image.altText: Police tape cordons off a section of Westfield Helensvale

items.synopsis: A security guard is in a serious condition in hospital after being attacked with a meat cleaver at a Gold Coast shopping centre. Police say a group of alleged offenders fled the scene in a stolen car.

title.children: Shopping centre stabbing captured on CCTV, security guard attacked with meat cleaver, police allege

image.altText: merino sheep graze on button grass plains with snow covered mountains in the background

items.synopsis: New Zealand is known for its jaw-dropping scenery, first-class food and wine, and sheep — lots of them. But their flock is now a third of what it was 40 years ago, and Aussies are stepping in with plenty of merino wool to sell.

title.children: New Zealand famously has more sheep than people. So why are we shipping our wool to them?

image.altText: a young person from Wear it Purple at this year's Sydney Gay and Lesbian mardi gras

items.synopsis: When Wear it Purple day was founded in 2010, LGBTQIA+ youth were experiencing high rates of discrimination, mental ill health, and homelessness. I wanted to help put a stop to that, writes Katherine Hudson.

title.children: Wear it Purple day started because LGBTQIA+ young people were in crisis. It has changed so much

image.altText: Cleared rainforest

items.synopsis: Millions of tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions are being wiped from company ledgers based on offsets generated from flawed forest conservation schemes, a new study has found.

title.children: Businesses use carbon credits to offset their emissions. A new study finds some aren't offsetting anything at all

image.altText: A woman wearing a white collared waistcoat sits in an auditorium crowd

items.synopsis: Yang Huiyan is the mysterious majority stakeholder of a sprawling real estate empire in China, but in a stunning reversal of fortune triggered by the country's ongoing property market woes, she is now locked in a desperate battle to prevent its collapse.

title.children: One of China's richest women is an elusive billionaire heiress. Her fortune was just cut in half

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

items.synopsis: The government is failing to convincingly explain the "unusual" decision to not let Qatar Airways expand in Australia at the same time that Treasurer Jim Chalmers is launching a review into competition policy, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: The case for more flights seems open and shut. The Albanese government has questions to answer

image.altText: A black and white photo of a man sitting in water under an old hang glider.

items.synopsis: When John Dickenson's unique design for a hang-glider first took flight over the Clarence River in 1963, it revolutionised aviation. Now, the 89-year-old's life and legacy is being commemorated.

title.children: 'Icarus's dream': Hang-gliding community bids farewell to the sport's founding father
